review_title: Depends on who and where you are
job_title: Front Line Agent in London, England
pros:
The front line staff are almost all great. The further you are away from the London HQ, the more likely it is that more people will be too.

Some of the incompetence shown by higher management is extremely funny. Until your job goes as a result, anyway.
cons:
The funding situation remains extremely uncertain. Shamefully, sexual health simply is not the priority it should be and 'treatment as prevention' has swallowed a great deal of health promotion money.

Far too much of the income goes to support the HQ rather than provide services.

review_title: Great charity but facing a tough time ahead
pros:
The most friendly and welcoming place I have ever worked - everyone is lovely
Smile and laugh every day 
Everyone pulls in the same direction 
A great sense of teamwork and passion
A great brand and respected name in the sector
A powerful and still very important cause
cons:
Haemorrhaging money - they are mostly grant funded and lots of local authority contracts are ending/cancelled meaning the run a huge deficit
They are starting to embark on a Transformation / Restructure which has so-far not been well handled by senior leadership
Many staff facing redundancies
Has been carried out with poor consultation - asking staff to review proposed solutions but not to input into its design from the start
Lots of uncertainty as to the charity's future shape direction and vision 
It will probably come out ok but 2018-19 is going to be a rough patch 
Pay - is good for sexual health sector but poor vs broader health sector

review_title: Poor management, internal communication and lack of transparency
pros: On a local level fab job and amazing team. Good support from those around you and a real sense of ownership of your role. Varied and interesting
cons:
The cons are once you need support from services or management level not based in your office it then becomes cloke and dagger. No communication. Lies. Changing of information or just a general vagueness so as not to be pinned down or held accountable. 

The organisation it very London focused. No actual idea for what it is like to live or work in rural locations.

If they make a mistake there is no apology or ownership. Just either ignore or pass the buck.

For a company built around supporting people, they show no support or compassion for their own staff.

This charity has gone through major restructuring with many staff leaving and new staff being brought in and it's working environment has suffered. I saw staff bullied in-house and it was tolerated by management. May be a HIV charity alleging working for the common good of this group of people but THT treat its own staff badly.
